review: I love my Chromecast.  I use Chrome (the browser) almost exclusively and found the transition to "casting" video to my TV completely flawless.  I can cast from YouTube or Netflix from my iPhone, too.  I'm looking forward to when I can cast from my (Android based) Kindle Fire, although it is possible I can already and I've not figured it out yet...In any case, if you're comfortable navigating between platforms and savvy about new apps, you shouldn't have a problem with Chromecast.  It is awesome.
author: Emily K

review: I've owned a GTV and enjoyed being able to fling YouTube videos from my phone to the TV. But then I had always wished for a way to fling songs from my phone's Google music player to the TV. Chromecasts remedies this and adds more and provides a seamless and smooth operation compared to GTV. It makes flinging Netflix, as well as Pandora, to the TV quick and simple. Simplicity is another plus of Chromecast. Setup is painless. And after that anyone with a smartphone or tablet can connect and start flinging content to the TV. At times I will battle it out with a friend flinging YouTube videos to the TV.A couple of tips to make the experience much better.1. Turn on the TV's CEC feature.2. Instead of plugging it in to the TV's USB port, plug it in to a constant power source.The CEC feature allows the TV to automatically switch the TV source input to the Chromecast when flinging content. And the constant power source paired with CEC allows Chromecast to automatically turn the TV on when flinging content. If plugging the Chromecast to the TV for power source, the TV might actually turn off the USB power and thus turn off Chromecast, making it unable to turn the TV on automatically.
author: David Kha
